top_comment.text:
Come on, there are no aliens, or life on other planets. Life on Earth is 
possible because of an extremely, *extremely* delicate balance of many 
different parameters, including earth's distance from the sun, its mass, 
its rotation speed, speed of its orbit, mass and size of the moon, the 
moon's exact, unbelievably precise balance in its own orbit around earth, 
etc etc etc etc...... If you modify any of these parameters by even less 
than 1%, there would be no life on earth at all. And then we get into the 
position of the solar system in the milky way, and the position of the 
milky way in the known universe, and so on.......

Even with billions and billions of other planets in the universe, the 
chance for any one of them being able to reliably sustain life at long term 
is so low that it's a scientific impossibility. Our planet is a magnificent 
ecosystem in which everything recycles to perfection - think about it, 
would blind chance create such a wonder out of a "big bang" and huge rock 
bodies randomly colliding in space, or was it created by a supremely 
intelligent, creative, and powerful Architect?

And, even if there theoretically was some form of (material) sentient life 
some millions of light years away, it would just be so unimaginably far, 
far away (in terms of physical distance) that it wouldn't even remotely 
concern us, at all.﻿

comments.author: Bob30737

comments.text:
+Bob30737 It's not a bias. It'd be much more difficult to find us if, say, 
the civilization had less advanced telescopes or didn't have radios. They 
could still find us, but it would be quite difficult since their tools 
would be less efficient and/or utterly incapable of detecting things that 
could lead to the detection of us.
comments.author: Apocalypse337

comments.text:
+Apocalypse337"it's not terrible likely that a civilization significantly 
less advanced than us would be capable of finding us"  BIAS
comments.author: Bob30737

comments.text:
It's generally assumed because the universe is so old, and our species is 
so young. While it's quite possible that alien races are less advanced than 
us, the shear amount of time that other civilizations would've had to 
advance virtually guarantees that many will be more advanced than us. In 
addition, it's not terrible likely that a civilization significantly less 
advanced than us would be capable of finding us; we'd have to find them, 
which isn't likely to be within our capability for some time. 

Another reason that it is assumed is due to the vast distances between 
stars. If, for example, a civilization that's technological advancement 
was, say, 100 years below ours at the time we received the signal, but they 
were 500 light years away, they would've had 500 years to advance before we 
got that signal.
comments.author: Apocalypse337

contact protocols when our own government refuses to admit that UFOs and

thousands of years.

it seems to be well beyond any further serious denial, Alien life is one of

     After studying the teachings of many, if not most, of the worlds 
religious fables, as well as the stories of many different and widely 
seperated indingenous tribal historical legends, they seem to (almost) all 
have the SAME STORY. god came down, made man, and created civilization.

our reality?

V I love your videos, I find your subjects fascinating even if I'm not 
entirely at one with your conclusions. (I feel like your a tad pessimistic 
some times) but I can't listen to your videos more than once a day. The 
pregnant pauses you use in your speech have a tendency to drive me up the 
wall. Your a smart guy and I want to hear what you have to say but I often 
feel like you pause in your speech to give me time to catch up and it makes 
me feel like your talking down to me as if I can't possibly be at your 
level. I know it's not on purpose or that your intent is to be irritating, 
but I felt like I should make you aware. Your a great guy and I'll keep 
watching regardless of how you speak. I will power through!﻿
top_comment.author: David Hopkins

comments.text:
+xxxrokkstarrxxx I had every intention to let the matter rest with Mr. 
Allen as promised, but I feel I must intercede when words are being put 
into my mouth that I did not utter. I have no quarrel with your final 
statement. In fact, should you care to look, my very first utterance into 
the subject was praise for V's efforts and in the same post I praise his 
intellect.

A therapists opinion need not be obtained as I am not sensitive to the 
point that I think people on YouTube are talking down to me and, (once 
again) should you care to look, during the conversation with Mr. Allen I 
say more than once that I am assured V's motivations are genuine. Perhaps 
in reading through my first post you missed the line where I said "I know 
that it is not on purpose or that your intent is to be irritating," 
Followed by an admission that I will continue to follow him regardless.

The issue is not what I "Think". The issue is what I "Feel". The feeling of 
irritation is comparable to the feeling that one has when you have spoken 
but the person you are speaking to has not heard a word, or has come up 
with an unintended meaning. I am indirectly speaking about this 
conversation of course.

Now I hope I have made clear that from a logical, self "thinking" 
standpoint I hold no ill motive or animosity against V. But, should you 
wish to debate further why I should not "Feel" irritated by the pregnant 
pauses, I promise your counterpoint will have as much effect as any 
argument I could come up with as to why you should.

That said I hope the rest of your day is a pleasant one.
comments.author: David Hopkins

comments.text:
"alien (adj.)
mid-14c., "strange, foreign," from Old French alien "alien, strange, 
foreign; an alien, stranger, foreigner," from Latin alienus "of or 
belonging to another, foreign, alien, strange," also, as a noun, "a 
stranger, foreigner," adjectival form of alius "(an)other" (see alias 
(adv.)). Meaning "not of the Earth" first recorded 1920. An alien priory 
(c.1500) is one owing obedience to a mother abbey in a foreign country."

It's a word used to describe anything foreign. It may have been used in pop 
culture to describe extraterrestrials; and then therefore stuck as 
distinguishable only for describing them and it's been used for that 
purpose since.

comments.text:
Lol. Study up on electromagnetic waves. You'll find that we've be blasting 
signals into space since the late early 1900s in the form of radio waves 
and micro waves (i.e. the spectrums that we conduct the majority of our 
communication on). This isn't preventable as the radiation is inherent to 
the process of transmitting and receiving wireless signals. Furthermore, a 
1 bit signal is basically useless for any form of communication. In fact, 
there is tons of background radiation, in relatively the same spectrum, 
being generated and sent through the universe by various cosmic entities 
(stars, black holes, etc.) at all times. In fact, every device that emits 
EM waves is kind of giving away our position at all times: TV's, Radios, 
Wireless APs, Radar Dishes, Satellites, EM based LoS systems, you name it. 
At any rate, this isn't a problem as It's kind of a prerequisite that a 
species evolve to cope and handle the various bands electromagnetic 
radiation in varying degrees.

top_comment.text:
The idea that aliens would respond to us like Columbus did toward the 
natives is completely stupid. Yes, there's the potential for something like 
that, but what reason do we have to believe that aliens would want anything 
from us?
Columbus wanted land and precious resources that humans had come to value. 
Why would aliens share our love of gold?
Columbus also was responding to what he saw as lesser humans, not animals. 
Aliens would see us the way we see animals. They might find us novel or 
interesting, or perhaps we wouldn't even be worth their time.
Maybe they'd cherish us, if we were the first intelligent life outside 
their own that they found-- validating their idea that there was life 
beyond their own.
The number of possible outcomes is infinite, so to think with any sureness 
that the outcome would mirror our own history of how we treat fellow humans 
is absolutely ridiculous.﻿
top_comment.author: Frank Stallone

comments.text:
THANK YOU! People always project their humanity on the aliens. For all we 
know, there are aliens that are completely devoid of the "survival of the 
fittest" instinct that we still have. Our ancestors had to evolve to 
survive wild animals that could kill them in one swipe, we needed that 
instinct to live.

There could easily be aliens completely devoid of things like selfishness 
or even fear, if the circumstances of their evolution deemed that they 
didn't need it, like say, if their entire planet was filled with an 
abundance of edible vegetation, all animals were small and mostly harmless, 
and the entire planet lacked carnivores or poisons.

Could there be extra-terrestrials like this? Maybe. Then, there could be 
ones who are even more violent that us do to harsh evolution on a harsh 
planet, they would need violent instincts to survive.

Or maybe their circumstances were similar to our own, they've just overcome 
any violent nature do to strong morals. The possibilities are endless, it 
is highly unlikely aliens will even be remotely similar to us.

top_comment.text:
I don't find Hawking's analogy to be very reasonable.  Columbus was an 
undereducated selfish prick looking to make a quick buck by establishing a 
new safe trade route with Asia.

I think it may be more prudent to look back at a different civilization in 
our history, if using ourselves as a template for alien behavior can be 
said to be prudent, anyway.  One with much more success than Columbus had, 
and one with an established academy of scientific and cultural advancement, 
which a space-faring race would likely have needed to achieve stellar 
travel:
Ancient Rome

The Romans conquered much of the known world.  But every new nation or 
culture they conquered, they did not enslave or destroy.  They assimilated 
its people AND its culture and religions into the greater bulk of Roman 
culture itself.  Once acquired, children of conquered noble families were 
taken as "hostages" back to Rome to be raised and educated there, and thus 
immersed and invested in the culture of greater Rome.  This peacefully 
ensured that the conquered nations would not rebel after the occupying 
forces withdrew, and that the new nation would benefit from- and provide 
benefit to- the empire as a whole.

Something similar could be the case if dealing with a social species 
advanced, intelligent, and successful enough to develop interstellar 
technology.  Perhaps some of our children, or groups of humans, would be 
taken up to other worlds, stations, or ships, to be immersed in a 
cumulative alien culture and be educated in advanced sciences and ethics.

In my opinion, this (or equal or better alternatives) are more likely than 
an uneducated, superstitious, greedy alien space captain looking for a 
wormhole to the other side of his civilization and finding us instead.﻿
top_comment.author: Lowraith

comments.text:
+coolcupcakequeen101 I am all for the core values that mainstream religions 
are built upon. However, the enormous "frames" that have been erected 
around these religions to support and promote them are now crushing and 
overshadowing those very values, focusing instead on image, popularity, and 
enforcement of "rules" that are starting to lose the meaning they were 
created for.

We as humans have grown to a point were we are able to discover, 
understand, and integrate into our lives the same values and virtues from 
which religions originate, without requiring management by external 
organizations. Understanding these values on its own is not an easy task, 
so there is definitely a need to nurture them into our society, as to teach 
everyone the right way to find a path toward happiness, acceptance, and 
cooperation.

Religions induce fear of the unknown into its followers, thereby hindering 
one of the most precious abilities that we have: curiosity. Without 
curiosity, one does not feel the need to undertake a journey into 
self-discovery, and without knowledge of oneself, we are merely reduced to 
the state of lab mice, living to follow the paths, goals, and rules 
established by people from a previous era that is long over.

We are able to do as much good as religions ever did and even more, but all 
individuals first need to come upon realization of their own potential and 
decisive power over their lives. Once we are finally able to cope with each 
other, live together, and share common goals, we will be able to relinquish 
religions and finally leave them to museums and history books, where they 
belong.

The human race is capable of so much more. We are all so different, yet so 
close to each other. If the appropriate choices are made, I know for sure 
that we will be able to use all of our potential toward making the world a 
better place to live for everyone.

top_comment.text:
We will probably need some form of world government before we are ready. We 
would need to abandon our primitive notions of nationality and race and 
start thinking on the level of our species as a whole and global interests 
rather than local ones. Even then we probably won't be ready. This 
hypothetical world government would then have to invest billions 
upon billions into space-related areas of travel, colonisation and (in case 
things go south in human - ET relations) military forces. Only when we have 
a firm foothold throughout our solar system (or beyond), when 
interplanetary travel becomes mundane and when we stand a fair chance in 
any armed confrontation should we pick up the "cosmic phone". Even if 
Aliens don't exist it's probably a good idea to aim for this anyway as it's 
only a matter of time until a meteor wipes us out. The only way to prevent 
that is to spread ourselves as far and wide in the cosmos as possible. At 
best I'd say world government will be feasible in about 1000 years.﻿

comments.text:
+Joku Tyyppi I did read your post (a comment would be just a sentence). 
There are no tricks, no magic bullet solution. There are no quick easy way 
towards some semblance of peace. Because people are complicated beings and 
humans are slow to change. Only the dead know a perfect peace. The 
strongest act you can perform is being vulnerable to others, understanding 
no one is perfect, and being able to forgive. How I do it is I try to live 
my life with those things in mind and having mental flexibility and 
resiliency to bounce back. And to this day, I always struggle with it; 
that's what I do. I don't believe in false bad endings or only playing into 
the hands of a false dichotomy. The dichotomy being presented is either: we 
may maintain our independence but have no real type of peace or just drop 
all our grievances of the past without want for justice all for the sake of 
peace under unification. We made it out the Bronze Age to the Industrial 
Age and now to the Information Era. Who would have thought it was all 
possible? You can choose anything for yourself. My ideal choice would 
ultimately be at peace even with once hostile extraterrestrial alien 
enemies. I can choose any ending I want to pursue; fuck reality's lame 
sorry ass choices, fuck false destinies.

+ozis ponas
I personally think that would be a good idea but issues over freedom of 
speech and religion and the trouble of distinguishing between true bigots 
(i.e. those that incite hatred) and people who are simply misinformed or 
are too stupid to know any better would prove difficult. No, overall 
re-education and marginalisation of such people would prove to be the best 
course: it involves less bloodshed (and clean-up). Often oppressing a group 
earns them a lot of sympathy and support even when they're objectively 
terrible people. So say if they were to round up all racists and 
imprison/liquidate them many would end up supporting the racists as an 
"oppressed" group and brand anti-racists as "tyrants". Most people just 
aren't prepared to accept extreme solutions like that. Marginalisation and 
re-education works (at least in part). Though what we see in the news 
everyday would suggest otherwise the world today is a lot less 
racist/religious/violent than it was only a century ago. In large part the 
reason for this is changing views and the marginalisation of old ones. Some 
racists nowadays would have been regarded as fine upstanding citizens in 
previous generations but their vile beliefs have no place in most of 
today's societies. It kind of shows that (though progress is painfully slow 
in some areas) human society does mature and "grow out of" such phases.

comments.text:
+N. Hail Although I can see the appeal of a "fresh start" I'd have to 
disagree. The world isn't beyond all hope, nor do I think it ever will be. 
Plus a fresh start wouldn't necessarily mean a better world. Much of our 
modern world is specialised. Not everyone can be an architect or 
a scientist or any other highly trained professional only those with the 
correct education. Unless special steps are taken to protect such 
specialists and sources of advanced knowledge (like books) then any wiping 
out of civilization would likely take a great deal of that skill and 
knowledge. Lets say that very few doctors or surgeons survive the "reset". 
Life expectancy would plummet as there wouldn't be enough people with 
medical training to tend to the sick or injured. Previously "eradicated" 
diseases would likely make a comeback as no co-ordinated efforts would be 
taking place to prevent or quarantine them. But doctors aren't the only 
specialists we would have need of. If farmers were in short 
supply then starvation would become an even greater threat as people 
wouldn't know the best places to plant crops or how to tend them. Life 
would become a brutal battle between warring tribes over scarce resources 
of food, medicine, knowledge and whatever working technologies are 
left (basically The Walking Dead without zombies). And speaking of 
technology, we would likely regress in that area as well due to a similar 
lack of specialists, parts and factories making new products. After a 
couple of generations it would be back to the horse and cart, to the spear 
and shield. You say we would have knowledge of our past mistakes. Sure, we 
would at first but not for long. Again many historians and historical 
documents may be lost to the reset and the few that are left would have 
little opportunity to make that knowledge useful. If you're in a tribe of 
survivors you want to join people who can be of use (doctors, farmers, 
hunters, warriors etc.) if someone's skills are "knows a lot of stuff that 
happened a long time ago" but nothing else, then they won't be of much use 
to the group in it's daily struggles. The fact that people would be reduced 
to small tribes and clans would also be a problem for any hope of world 
government. It would be like turning back the clocks back hundreds of 
thousands of years. We would have to build new villages, towns, cities and 
nations. In short, all the progress of human history: world wars, civil 
rights, religious beliefs, *everything* that has ever happened since the 
first human rubbed one twig against another to make fire would have been a 
complete and utter waste of time. A reset sounds good when you don't think 
too hard about it but when you do it turns out to be pretty horrifying.
comments.author: kingkong381

comments.text:
+CanineArachnid The exact form of government could vary pretty wildly 
depending on the situation of how it came to be. For example: it could be a 
large-scale version of US politics where you have a number of local 
governments which all submit to the authority of a federal government and 
elected head of state. Another possibility is a "modern Napoleon" where a 
visionary leader will forge an empire (kind of like the Emperor in 
Warhammer 40k). One person being in charge isn't an inherently bad thing. A 
dictatorship is only as bad as it's dictator after all. However I doubt 
this will be what happens as if someone set out to conquer the world (even 
if it was in a well-intentioned manner) a number of less receptive states 
would almost certainly ally with one another to bring said leader down. 
Left-wing ideologies like Marxism have internationalist aims but their 
ultimate vision of successful revolution involves the state fading away 
once an equal society is established. Call me a pessimist but as nice as 
that sounds you need some kind of government structure if you intend to set 
up colonies on other planets and I just can't envisage a stateless, 
communal society doing that.

It seems likely to me that unification will be a gradual process going from 
local to continental and finally global stages. For example, I live in 
Scotland. First we would have to abandon the notion of Scottish 
independence so that the British Isles are truly united. Then we would have 
to support greater integration with Europe (in the case of Britain that 
will involve abolition of the Monarchy - the same goes for other 
monarchies). If that goes well we would end up with a unified Europe (this 
isn't something that would happen solely in Europe though - similar events 
would hopefully occur in Asia, Africa, America etc.). Finally all the 
unified continents would have to come to some sort of agreement on world 
government. Ideally, this would all play out without any major wars but you 
can never be too sure about these things. Ultimately though, the form and 
evolution of world government isn't as important as the end goal. That's 
just my best case scenario.
comments.author: kingkong381

comments.text:
+Felix Hunter Scientists are not assuming out of thin air that Aliens would 
have better technology than ours. Obviously, they could be a lower 
civilization or maybe just as advanced as ours. 

The reason why scientists take for granted the fact that if Intelligent 
Life forms would visit us, they would be technologically superior, is 
because they would be the one 'paying a visit'. In all these years of 
modern technology and space exploration, one thing is clear to us, the 
vastness of the universe and the adversities to overcome in order to make 
interstellar trips.

Therefore, if Intelligent extraterrestrial beings, were to visit us, it's 
reasonable to think that they would have the greater technology, because so 
far we can't even send men outside this solar system and bring them back 
alive.

spread out and away from this planet sometime in the future. There have 
been several proposals by scientists on terraforming mars to make it 
habitable by humans. And the human fantasy of spreading life further out in 
the universe from earth is gonna keep living until we actually do something 
about it. I would imagine that the first step would be to make mars 
habitable by humans. Spreading further out from this solar system is far 
trickier, granted. Maybe it is not possible to travel the distances between 
stars in a human generation. If we were to plan a manned mission to a 
foreign star that trip would probably take many human generations and the 
whole spaceship would have to be some kind of ecosystem with artificial 
gravity that could sustain a breeding human population for generations. In 
such a scenario we would probably have sent out an unmanned mission prior, 
containing some seed of life that could be planted by some of our robots on 
a suitable exoplanet. There it would transform the environment so it was 
ready for our arrival and we would know in advance that we would come to a 
place where we could breathe the air. Maybe for whatever reason however, it 
could be that it's just not possible for humans to make such a grand trip 
to foreign stars across several generations. Then all the humans would stay 
here on earth, but i still think that we would probably try and send some 
sort of earthly lifeform that could survive the trip to other star-systems, 
such as bacterias, just for the hell of it :P In fact life on earth could 
have started and evolved to the point we're at today because some ancient 
civilisation did something similar to that a few billions years ago ;)

conditions, but is the intelligent part of life really dependent on 
conditions or something else? I don't know what that factor would be but I 
guess chance plays a big role in it.
comments.author: Andre Yanez

comments.text:
+Mark Scott I notice distance is your only concern. Why don't you mention 
time? I'm not trying to argue possibilities of life outside of earth, since 
like you said with an infinite universe it is bound to happen. I'm just 
trying to bring up things most people don't think about. Two of them being, 
why aren't there two human like beings on our planet and people need to 
realize that the time factor adds another infinity to the equation.
Another way to think about it is if me and you were both given infinite 
attempts at slots we would both eventually win. But what are the chances of 
us winning at the same time? Or even within 1000 attempts of each other?
I guess the real thing I'm trying to bring up is that life in the universe 
comes and goes relatively quickly it doesn't come and then stay around 
forever waiting for the next life to pop up(although it's not impossible, 
because nothing is right lol?).
The only thing that I can think of that would go against my logic is that 
if the universe was created at one single moment, then a lot of stars and 
planets would evolve at the same rate which would make it more likely for 2 
life giving planets to pop up at a similar time frame.
Sorry for the book. Just hope people actually get what I'm trying to say.
comments.author: Andre Yanez

comments.text:
+Andre Yanez We are proof that it is possible, that we know for certain. 
"If" the universe is infinate then there are an infinate number of 
possibiities which makes anther earth like planet with human beings 
inhabiting it an absolute certainty. How far away from us that planet or 
planets would be, well that is the most baffling part of the equation.
comments.author: Mark Scott

comments.text:

I think people under appreciate that how lucky life on any planet really 
is. Another thing people take for granted is immortality. For some reason

extraterrestrial life will be around for ever but chances are that life 
will end before getting to inter solar levels not only for us but for the 
ET's too. People like to dream that with enough time humans will eventually 
rule the universe, but the reality of that is just as unlikely as our 
existence in the first place.
comments.author: Andre Yanez

comments.text:
I can see where you're coming from with that skepticism, and maybe we are a

our own. Whether they are close enough, or have the means, to communicate 
or even visit us, however, can definitely be called into question. I 
personally think that there very well might be extraterrestrial life out 
there, but I also think it's very unlikely that they would be close enough 
to us for any sort of interaction. At least at this point in time.

comments.text:
+3LM0TH3REAP3R Yeah I get that the odds mean that there will be life 
somewhere else. But what are the odds that there will be another like us? 
That can't be quantified. That's like trying to quantify the chances of 
someone having the exact same finger print as me. There are equally 
infinite fingerprints to go along with the infinite amount of people. So 
chances are that if there is life the species won't be exactly the same as 
any other species in the universe. And based off what we experience on 
earth the intelligence we have may be just as unique. Obviously with 
infinity anything is possible, but I'm just pointing out that it may be a 
lot smaller chance than people really think. And the infinity actually does 
have a limit so not only in matter but in our time of existence. Who's to 
say we will exist for ever? So if you want to talk about infinite time, 
chances are infinitely less that two intelligent species will be alive at 
one time even if on opposite sides of the universe.

top_comment.text:
The Fermi Paradox is ridiculous and frustrating because it isn't a paradox. 
We don't have the technology to search for extraterrestrial life yet. 
Pointing radios at the sky and waiting for it to decide to contact us isn't 
'searching' so much as it is 'keeping our fingers crossed and hoping we get 
really really really lucky'. Why hasn't intelligent life managed to detect 
us and tried to contact us with radio technology specifically during the 
.055% of human history that we've been communicating with radio technology? 
It isn't a paradox, it's a stupid question.﻿

that can be refined and weaponised, meaning aliens might have fewer weapons 
of mass destruction then we do. In the mid 90s we still had 3 times the

about complete planetary destruction) inhabitable.
I get your point though, that nuke-thing probably isn't a huge reason not 
to visit earth.
I still think it will never be possible to fly at lightspeed or faster, it 
would make absolutely no sence to me and my picture of the universe.

comments.author: FourKelvin

comments.text:
+FourKelvin
First, earth has never had and still doesn't have enough warheads to 
destroy the planet. There are enough to kill all humans, but that is a far 
cry from planetary destruction.
Second, interstellar travel at sub-light speed is very possible through a 
verity of means. Longer lives. Stasis technology. Generation ships. Then 
theres that fun thing called relativity where your subjective experience of 
time is SEVERELY shortened, so subjectively you have not traveled for 
nearly as long as it took to get there from an outside perspective.

You have made two large assumptions. First was that human weapons are not 
only respectably powered from the perspective of a people who can travel 
between stars (we can't really even reach the bottom of the ocean), but 
that they are more powerful than they are.
Second: That they would suffer from limitations that don't necessarily even 
exist. The nearest planet that has the highest probability of earth like 
life is some 37 light years away. Not very far.

top_comment.text:
There's no way that humanity is ready to meet life from outside our world. 
The guys from Roosterteeth put it well when they found a video of a guy 
cutting open what appeared to be a rock with blood and guts... What if any 
alien race does that to us? "Hey, never seen these things before, let's gut 
them and see what the hell they are."

I always put this in terms of every science fiction show I've seen.

We may not meet the Vulcans, but the Borg... We may not find the Minbari, 
but the Shadows... or the Bugs... or the Xenomorphs... or Q!

There are probably (hopefully) many different lifeforms out there beyond 
our solar system, and while I would love to be drawn into an alliance of 
super-intelligent species who only want to help our little human race 
develop into a galactic superpower, we could just as likely be smashed into 
a million pieces without ever knowing it because some entity that we don't 
understand sneezed on the earth.﻿

comments.text:
+Raymon Danielson It's horrible that no one can measure and test this to 
know for sure. I'm aware that reality works in far more complex ways than 
the fraction today's science is able to see... but I also can't accept 
beliefs as fact if there's not at least strong indication of them.

The only thing I'm certain of is that consciousness is not an illusion in 
the brain, and that spirits exist and are interfaced with the brain through 
some special part of the neural network. In case I'm right, and in case 
there are aliens on other planets in this universe, not much is stopping 
the conscious self of an alien from being born as a person.

I'm not sure how different density matter can work though. It's tricky to 
think how a living being, made out of atoms and organs and electrochemical 
signals like Earth life, can exist in the same location without causing any 
form of interaction (excluding a parallel spacetime). Really wish there was 
more to work with, but the little that's probably known is mostly under 
skepticism.

comments.text:
Lets unpack what you said Elliot. So, you're insulting this gentleman as 
being an, and I'm quoting you here, 'unnatural piece of shit' because of 
sarcasm. Sarcasm is unnatural for a man because its feminine, is that the 
crux of your argument?

You... you do realize that the male brain still creates estrogen, right? 
Just because you have a penis doesn't mean estrogen disappears. If you want 
to talk about artificial constructs, your binary notion of male/female 
paradigm is more artificial - the trait of sarcasm being feminine has 
nothing to do with hormones, chromosomes, or genitalia. Its a learned trait.

Lets expand a bit further. You called him unnatural. Over the internet. 
Using some form of a computer. News flash - human's don't act very natural. 
The very act of making and using tools in unnatural - wood, metals, and 
silicon all appear in nature, but the way we process them into instruments 
is not. You'll never see a Mac Book blossoming in nature. Its ironic that 
you're calling someone unnatural because of a personality trait - something 
from their brain, over the internet - which is as far from natural as we've 
come.

Now, to unpack your message. He never said that Aliens don't exist. His 
argument was about conspiracy theorists.

Now, saying that its possible that other organic organisms live out in the 
cosmos is one thing. Saying they've been to Earth is another.

There has been no definitive physical proof that aliens exist. You can 
point to things like The Drake Equation, which mathematically set out to 
prove that we are not alone (it estimates about 9 other empires should 
exist, but it fluctuates wildly based on the inputs), but there is no 
tangible proof. No alien corpses. No tissue samples. No crafts. No leaked 
technology. No leaked photos. Not even an instrument - something as mundane 
as an eating utensil, which could be cross analyzed to determine its 
origin, makeup, etc. Nothing.

And to say none of this has leaked in the entirety of world history due to 
a shadowy cabal of people who want to keep it secret because... reasons... 
is a conspiracy theory.

If you want to argue that in some far off section of the galaxy there are 
proteins that have assembled into lifeforms is a completely different 
debate then "They're here".

Columbus and aliens is, Columbus is extraordinarily less intelligent than

comments.text:
+Paul Sveg
I mean, the universe is billions of year old. Humans haven't been around 
for even a million years. If an Earth like planet formed before Earth did, 
and followed a similar process of evolution, they could be several million 
years more advanced than us. Which would make them capable of things beyond 
our imaginations. I mean, NASA is planning to set foot on Mars with a 
living human being by 2030. And that is not a one way trip. Imagine what we 
will be capable of in just 50 years. If I had to guess, I would say that we 
will have interstellar travel capabilities within 500 years. And that is 
being generous. We will definitely have a warp drive of some sort in 100 
years, assuming that it is possible, of course. Just look at how quickly we 
have advanced in technology. 100 years ago, radio was barely a thing, now 
we are sending and receiving radio signals to and from hundreds of 
light-years  away. It doesn't take long to become intelligent. Plus, 
statistics are not wrong as much as you think. Perhaps you should actually 
do some research into this topic before you start bashing it with your own 
crazy ideas that aren't even close to being true. There are likely 10's if 
not 100's of thousands of planets that could support life in our own 
galaxy. And there are 10's if not 100's of thousands of galaxy's. Most of 
them bigger than ours. We are not alone in the universe. Also, we aren't as 
lucky to be this intelligent as you think we are. Yes, it is true that it 
is strange how we suddenly jumped in our mental capabilities and still 
don't know how, but even just looking at other animals on Earth, we aren't 
the only intelligent species. We are the most intelligent species on Earth, 
but not the only one. Dogs, apes, dolphins are all examples of highly 
intelligent creatures capable of thought processes. Then can all be taught 
math and language. Hell, some of these creatures are a lot smarter than 
some people.
comments.author: notbob555

comments.text:

comments.author: Paul Sveg

comments.text:
+Paul Sveg
Paul is pretty much wrong simply because he is just guessing and ignoring 
the actual math. If you did the math, it would be nearly impossible 
statistically for there to not be another planet with life similar to Earth 
in the observable universe, which we know is a lot smaller than the whole 
universe. Statistically speaking, there is planet out there that is exactly 
the same as Earth, there is another you, saying the exact same thing at the 
exact same time. All of this is also for life similar to that of life on 
Earth. If you take into account the possibility for life different from 
that of Earth, then the odds just continue to increase. It is simply a fact 
that it is more likely for there to be intelligent life out there than  for 
there to be no intelligent life out there. Hell, we've found microbes in 
meteorites. That is all you need to seed a planet that has the right 
conditions.

top_comment.text:
... and what if communication isn't even possible?
In face to face communication we humans use the voice, which is controlled 
fluctuation of sound waves. Fortunately we have ears that can detect these 
sound waves and a mechanism that can interpret them.
But what is being transmitted and interpreted? Well, we're transmitting 
sounds that are culturally accepted to represent ideas. If you understand 
English and I say the word "frog" you hear the word "frog" and we both 
understand that "frog" is a symbol for an amphibious creature. It happens 
automatically.
But if I say the English word "frog" and you speak German chances are you 
will hear the word "frag" and think I've said "question."
Okay, because we're both human beings we share a common body type and a 
common understanding of the world we can still establish a limited kind of 
communication by using hand signals. But again, hand signals are a 
culturally accepted symbolism and in this case I mean human culture.
The Earth is filled with millions of different kinds of animals, but the 
number of animals we communicate with is very, very small. Dogs can learn 
to understand a limited number of words, and they're actually very good at 
understanding human body language. Some dolphins have learned to understand 
some human words and symbols- and I can't help but point out that if we're 
so smart it ought to be the other way around.
We know that bees communicate through a sort of dance, but we haven't 
learned how to communicate with them. Ants apparently communicate through 
the use of pheromones, but we're not whipping up batches of pheromones to 
talk to them.
Because we don't know how their communication works, what it's symbolism is.
Chances are we have more in common with dogs, dolphins, bees and ants than 
we will with an alien species.
Ah ha, you say, but we will share an intellect, an intelligence, with any 
alien species sufficiently advanced enough to attempt to establish 
communication. There are any number of earthly creatures who exhibit what 
we call intelligence.
And we have math!  Well, math may or may not be a universal truth. 
Currently we believe it is, and that theory is called Mathematical Realism. 
It postulates that math is an inherent feature of the universe and that it 
exists as surely as light or matter.
The other viewpoint is that math is an invention of mankind that has proven 
to be a wonderful tool in understanding and explaining the universe.
Just because we have discovered radio waves, and cannot imagine an advanced 
race of aliens who also haven't discovered radio waves, doesn't mean that 
aliens will be using radio waves as a calling card. What it does mean is 
that we lack the imagination to consider other forms of communication that 
aliens might be using.
We're too Earth-centric at this point.﻿

top_comment.text:
One of the things no one seems to bring up is time. There could have been a 
super advanced culture at one time but has since longed declined or even 
disappeared. Any radio signals (or other types of communication) could take 
thousands, hundreds of thousands or millions of years to reach us. And by 
that time the signal could be so garbled that it's unrecognizable. Or there 
is also the possibility that everyone is at the same basic technological 
level and simply have no means to contact us even if they wanted to. 
Besides all of that if there were an advanced culture would they even 
bother with radio signals as a form of communication across space? Any kind 
of fast communication across the universe would probably use some sort of 
light technology shot though artificial worm holes, in other words 
by-passing space altogether. ﻿

comments.text:
+bowser jr
Exactly, I'm glad you made that point (cells on their own are considered 
alive, but they're not themselves composed of cells). This concept has been 
bothering me for a while now. It seems to me everything in the universe 
does begin (is born), grows (changes), (has the opportunity to) reproduce, 
and ends (dies). So, that pattern is just everywhere. Stars do that, rocks 
do that. Everything follows that pattern in one way or another. It seems to 
me that we confuse ourselves when we say that life has to be made of cells, 
and we have too narrow a perspective to understand the many forms of life 
that saturate the universe. If cells are alive because they're the smallest 
unit of a living thing, then organelles also have to be alive since cells 
are composed of organelles. If organelles are alive, then how can we say 
DNA, proteins, compounds and molecules are not? I think we just draw the 
line at cells and typically ignore everything smaller we don't understand. 
It makes sense to us that living cells make up a living body, but we then 
say that the cell is made up of non-living stuff, which seems odd. If 
non-living stuff is at the core of everything, that means we're not really 
alive either, we only believe we are. We think we're a group of cells, a 
living organism, but we're just an even larger group of dead molecules and 
atoms. Either 'everything that is' is alive or it's all not living but 
creating illusions of life. But then again I think our concepts of life and 
death are probably poor descriptors of reality. So, no I don't think we'll 
ever know LOL. We can use science to make our lives more convenient and 
face the challenges of poverty, hunger and environmental crises, but I 
guess we'll never find the answers to the fundamental philosophical 
questions.

top_comment.text:
I have a theory that explains the Fermi Paradox AND makes a prediction 
about how aliens would behave towards us (maybe someone has already come up 
with it but if they have I'm not aware of it). The theory assumes that most 
alien civilizations will develop a technology like our fossil fuel-based 
industry, which has the potential to destroy themselves. The only way to 
stop this happening is for said civilization to work together and stop that 
happening, which will only happen in a civilization likely to be peaceful 
and easy to compromise with.

The reason this explains the Fermi Paradox is that generally the most 
intelligent species are carnivorous, they eat other intelligent species in 
order to get the materials they need to be intelligent. That means they 
have a tendency to be aggressive and overuse surrounding resources, it also 
makes them less able to agree with each other and more territorial. So, if 
the majority of civilizations are aggressive, and in order to survive to 
reach a spacefaring age they need to become peaceful, then most intelligent 
civilizations will die out at around the stage of development humans are at 
this century.

This also predicts the way civilizations who survive will behave. They will 
either be friendly towards us because that's in their nature that allowed 
them to survive, or if they are so advanced they don't see us as 
intelligent, they will just ignore us to preserve the natural environment, 
also in their nature.﻿

comments.text:
+Kommander Rahnn Simply put: there isn't enough data to extrapolate to a 
logical conclusion. We have no clue what the future technology holds, if 
any. Do we have ideas of warp? Sure. Will they work? Nobody knows. A lot of 
old theories where proven wrong... and some where proven right. Is there 
alien life in the universe? based on statistics and the probability for 
similar planets to our own: there is alien life... somewhere out there. No 
point in making any sort of calculations here: space traveling is, for now, 
just a dream. The reason I can't say what future holds is simple: look at 
transistors and computers..nobody in the 50's predicted this stuff. Sure 
traveling in space is quite different then making a transistor. All I am 
trying to say is we don't know the future. We may never travel interstellar 
distances. Maybe we could teleport to other planets.. and then again, maybe 
not. based on current science though... things don't looks so good. So for 
now we can dream, Imagine ourselves heroes across the vastness of space. I 
myself prefer a positive attitude. Even though we are at the brink of 
killing ourselves off as a species I still prefer to say: yay, go science 
and go peoples.

Am I the only person who think aliens won't give a shit about us?? 

If they're advanced enough to be travelling the cosmos and all we've done 
is touched our only natural satellite a time or two and sent out a few 
telescopes they'll have no need for us whatsoever. The Earth will be to 
them what an anthill is to us, devoid of any purpose to serve to them. They 
might not even notice. 

I think it's very likely we've already been observed by an alien race just 
for them to come to the conclusion that there is no intelligent life on 
earth. They'll probably view our religions, governments, currencies, etc. 
as a sign that we are far less intelligent than they are. In fact we'd 
probably be able to understand their societies and technologies as well as 
a cat understands ours. ﻿

comments.text:
+BonDieu617 A lot of elements we know about are suited to support life. 
Those deep sea creatures are able to live from the volcanic gasses coming 
out of the bottom of the sea.

What many people do not realize is that we should not only look at the 
"Goldy Lock" planets we have discovered/discover, we should also look at 
the planets with extreme conditions. A planet which is ice cold could 
support life, although it will probably not be based upon water. Liquid 
nitrogen is able to do the exact same thing as water in freezing 
temperatures (and with freezing I mean 77K or -177°C). In those conditions 
nitrogen is able to do the exact same thing as water (source: Into the 
universe s1e1 "Aliens").

Discovery Channel created a very understandable and quite fun documentary 
with Steven Hawking, where Hawking talked about alien life. He explains 
everything from biological rules to alternatives which could also support 
life.

Funny to read you have learned a lot of our conversation, I am no expert in 
this thing, I am just a guy really interested in this stuff ;-)
comments.author: Syphr54

comments.text:
+Syphr54 There are indeed basic rules life in general seems to follow. I do 
agree that, for there to be intelligence, there must be a certain 'central' 
organ to be able to do anything remotely coherent, whether on a microscopic 
or on a planetary scale (as we don't know the limits of life). Still, even 
with this one LCA that everything evolved from, we can see deep in some 
acid lakes lifeforms based on amino acids containing materials poisonous to 
almost every other lifeform on earth, making the possibilities seemingly 
limitless: what if every single material in this universe can be part of an 
organisms base structure? That broadens the concept of life immensely. All 
this is purely hypothetical though, and I'm afraid I don't have sufficient 
biological knowledge to present a well-argumented and factual hypothesis. I 
have been learning a lot from this conversation, however.
comments.author: BonDieu617

comments.text:
+BonDieu617 I agree, but life still has to follow laws in biology and 
physics. Sure, it could be possible there is life in Jupiter's clouds 
(Steven Hawking's storm jellyfishes anyone?) or on Venus, but an 
intelligent life form, thus meaning it has a sense of living, has instinct 
and a conscious, must have specific things to be able to be intelligent, 
like a "brain". Sure, it is not a mandatory thing every individual being 
must have a brain, a hive mind which communicates with telepathy could be 
possible, but there has to be a leader with the brains to do it. 

Life needs energy to be able to live, intelligence needs energy to be 
there. That is one biological rule all forms of life have to follow. Even 
the most primitive bacteria on our Earth show some signs of primitive 
intelligence, and they all need certain elements to be able to produce 
energy to live on. An intelligent cloud of, for example, methane just isn't 
possible, as it has no possible means to extract energy from other sources 
to be able to feed the thinking processes. Another problem will be: where 
do these thinking processes take place? Like I said before, there must be 
some central "room" where all this stuff happens.

Evolution is a thing that is never finished and is incredibly variable, our 
Earth could have looked very different when not we, but another race would 
have lived on instead of the Homo Sapiens. Still, even if there is a planet 
with life and its origins are from a not comparable "Last Common Ancestor", 
the sentient race still has to follow a path that is laid out by the laws 
of biology and physics. Yes, there is no way we already know everything 
from life as we know it. We do not even know what are brains are capable 
of. Maybe there are aliens who are able to use the power of their minds to 
influence the world around them. And maybe they don't eat like we do, but 
constantly burn methane inside their bodies to produce the energy to be 
able to fuel those thought processes.

Things you name as examples of life are possible, but highly unlikely in a 
chain of evolution. I agree, we do not have the right mindset to recognise 
everything immediately as life when we meet it, but there are some ground 
rules we found out, that life has to follow to be able to be there.
comments.author: Syphr54

comments.text:
+Syphr54 You bring good arguments, but I'll have to quote you on something: *"regarding 
**our** biological situation"* is indeed correct, but it isn't sufficient. 
Think about it: all life on earth evolved from the Last Common Ancestor 
(the holy grail of evolutionary biology), which was created (an 
infinitesimally small chance) and thus formed the basis for all life on 
Earth. What if life evolved from other planets from another common 
ancestor? It would be completely unimaginable for us, simply because we 
wouldn't know what to imagine; both how it would look like as how it would 
'think' would be completely and utterly eldritch. We -and thus our view on 
life itself - are severely limited by our own psychology. Alien life will 
probably be completely different from what even the most visionary human 
could imagine, simply because, as all we know comes from a single planet, 
we don't know the limitations. Maybe some form of intelligent life inhabits 
Venus' clouds, or Jupiter's storms, without even trying to hide: we would 
never even know unless something extraordinary happened.
comments.author: BonDieu617

comments.text:
+BonDieu617 I think you have to think about biological boundaries. The 
knowledge of aliens as we see them is based upon our understanding of 
biological "rules". Every form of life as we know it, follows a specific 
set of rules to be able to live and be adapted to your surroundings. 

Think of those rules like this, if there are two identical lifeforms, but 
one has the ability to see like we do and another is able to see gamma 
rays. Which one will have a better chance to survive in a hostile 
environment full of predators?

Another thing you have to think about is something psychological. Is it 
efficient to communicate through gamma waves? How do you want to do that? 
If you were looking for another developed alien race, would you use such an 
advanced means of communication?

Radio waves are by far the easiest to send and receive, regarding our 
biological situation. If we would have a hearing that would us allow to 
hear microwaves or even higher energy frequencies? Wouldn't we get insane? 
We would hear the warmth of the Earth, how would that help communicating 
with each other?
comments.author: Syphr54

comments.text:
+Naveronasis I'm not stating that they haven't discovered radiowaves (that 
would be rather improbable), only that the probability of them utilizing 
them in a similar manner to ours is extremely low. I can imagine them 
communicating through gamma rays or in fluctuations of lightspectra, which 
would be more durable and faster than radiowaves. We can still look for 
them, no doubt about that, but I don't expect any alien radiowaves to be a 
means of communication.
comments.author: BonDieu617

comments.text:
Radio waves are not only simple technology so very likely to be invented by 
an a advanced civilization but they break down slower allowing them to 
travel much further, Their apparent use as long range communications is 
also prevalent in the universe in the form of pulsar's and so even if they 
didn't independently discover "the radio" they if they were sufficiently 
intelligent to discover electromagnetism (a prime force of the universe) 
would eventually discover radio waves emitted over millions of light-years 
with virtually no decay by pulsars and would if seeking to communicate 
messages over long distances develop radio technology to emit those 
signals. Also are you suggesting our alternative should be not to look at 
all?

comments.text:
+Sven Gren  Actually, you cannot prove that something does not exist. You 
can 'show' that there is an unicorn in your backyard, but you cannot show 
that there isn't. It might be hiding behind the next bush, or the next 
tree. Scientific theories get 'proven' with every bush you did not find an 
unicorn in, and it becomes rational to believe the theory once the number 
of bushes checked becomes significant.

Philosophically, all beliefs are viable. We have checked our backyards in 
years and have seen no unicorns - so it is rational to assume that the next 
time we check, we will not see one. As for planets similar to Earth, we 
have checked none. Statistics my ass - all numbers in the Drake equation 
are pretty much made up. Until we have actually checked a significant part 
of our galaxy, or until we find other life, we can only say that we don't 
know.

What if, humans like us existed on another planet, and we shared similar 
ideas, like Aliens being tall, grey and big headed creatures with 
abnormally sized heads, but instead, they could be exactly like us. the 
only thing different would be them speaking foreign languages. In Star 
Wars, the human citizens know how to speak English, and so do other 
species. But, they are in a completely different solar system, in a 
completely different time period. Unless they are given English voices, the 
theories are endless. If they were to come to earth, why start as cavemen 
or neanderthals? Why wouldn't they be as intelligent as they were in their 
solar system? Also, those planets might not have originally been life 
supporting, like Mustafar. Where does the Oxygen come from? It's obvious 
they need oxygen because they might not be humans, but they can choke to 
death. Maybe they don't breathe oxygen? If so, what do they breathe? And a 
similar question, what do all of those alien creatures breathe? But, that's 
just Star Wars. Just a Science Fiction entertainment series. If there are 
aliens out there though, what do they think of us? We are E.T.'s to them, 
and they are E.T.'s to us. We would have a similar title to each other, but 
not the same appearance or mindset of who we are, or what we're capable of. 
Unless they have been watching us, the only possible reasons for them to 
attack us would be if they are just bloodthirsty animals, or if they saw 
what humans could do. And if they do see what we can do, what would they do 
about it? Would they be scared? Would they be our friend? Would they try to 
steal our equipment? Would they give us better things? We don't know. We 
can't know for sure unless it happens to us personally. Things like this 
take a lot of time explaining, and a lot of time to think about what you;re 
saying about it.﻿

comments.text:

have evolved from primates and adapted to our environments changing our

etc.
  There could be E.T. life forms out there, watching us. Or as Neil 
deGrasse Tyson said:  
"There’s a worm in the street, you walk by it. Does the worm know that you 
think you’re smart? The worm has no concept of your smarts. Because you’re 
that much smarter than the worm. So the worm has no idea that something 
smart is walking by it. Which makes me wonder whether we have any 
concept—if a super species walked by us. Maybe they’re uninterested in us 
because we’re too stupid for them to even imagine having a conversation. 
You don’t walk by worms and go “Gee I wonder what the worm is thinking.” 
This is just not a thought that you have! So one of the best pieces of 
evidence for why we haven’t been visited by aliens is that they have 
actually observed us, and concluded there is no intelligent sign of life on 
earth."

comments.text:
a funny idea, but unlikely. Life will most likely develop very differently 
due to different circumstances (on alien planets). A different medium of 
atmosphere for example as you stated. But there are some conclusions that 
can be drawn just by assessing us humans and how we became what we are.

Highly evolved lifeforms must exhibit certain physiological and mental 
traits. First of all would be something that allows them to use and operate 
complex contraptions. A.K.A something like hands.

They also need to be capable of conveying information, as we do through 
speech. I would dismiss telepathy just because in a evolutionary point of 
view, it's much easier to just produce noises than to develop superbrains 
we can't even imagine.

It is also most likely, that they need a lot of energy, as we do. Oxygen 
does provide that and it is very common. The evolution of respiration gave 
us extraordinary amounts of energy compared to non oxygen "breathers" like 
deep sea microbes, which only make usage of the nitrate cycle. This energy 
helped to fasten further evolution and gave us an edge over the competition.

Another very important point is knowledge. When evolution comes to a 
certain point, scientific and philosophical advances matter more and more. 
Without a method of storing knowledge, it becomes increasingly difficult to 
go further. We used stone, papyrus, books and then digital methods for that.

TL;DR. Any highly evolved life form needs:

Functional appendages
A way of conveying information
High production/consumption of energy
A method to store knowledge

There are more things, just google search it

apart from that, almost everything is possible.

And now I will leave the discussion to you, I have already put more time in 
this than i originally intended xD.

comments.text:
+Lars Brodersen You are obviously not understanding me. The char size is 
~typically~ the byte size, which is what I'm talking about.

Most commonly, bytes are 8 bits, but this is not always the case. We used 
to use 6 bit bytes. If their char size (aka. byte size) is different, the 
bits will be shifted and values be incorrect.

000000110000000100000100

In 8 bit bytes would be {3 1 4} but in 6 bit bytes would be {0 48 4 4}. We 
do not know what the char size of their architecture would be.
comments.author: Daemon Ryuou

comments.text:
+Daemon Ryuou
Your whole idea that you have to use chars to represent binary numbers is 
wrong in this case. Instead of the decimal representation of binary numbers 
you use something like 2^(-n) for each digit after the decimal point. Thus 
pi looks like this:
11.0010010000
meaning 
2^1 +2^0 + 2^-3 + 2^-6 ...
comments.author: Lars Brodersen

comments.text:
+maca12345678 Reread my statement please... I wasn't talking about binary, 
I wasn't talking about binary, I was talking about char size. If the char 
(byte) size is different, the represented value will be different. {3 1 4} 
with 8-bit chars would be {0 48 4 4} with 6-bit chars. The value is 
completely different. Not to mention this shifting of the bits would also 
obliterate any repeating pattern we would send.

But coming back, I already addressed the problem that we could not even 
ascertain if they are using a binary, trinary, or quaternary architecture. 
You're literally just repeated back my own argument to me.


So yeah. We are making way to many assumptions about them. We are assuming 
that their mathematics, language, number system, writing, processor 
architecture, digital formats, transmission frequencies, transmission 
protocols, and ship design all fall within a very narrow category of what 
deem is the "best" or "only" way they could be done; or rather, the way we 
do it. With that kind of mind set, it's no wonder no aliens have been found.

+Daemon Ryuou of course we must choose a number system if we are to build a

since they are electronic devices we use base 2 over base 10 since bits are

if computers weren't base 2 then the size of any variable, which is the

comments.text:
+Darek Amadeus You have no idea what the hell you're talking about.

Firstly, we don't build computers in bases, we build them with different 
char and word sizes. While most common is 8-bits per char (byte), we have 
used different sizes before, and if they're using a different char size it 
would screw up transmission. For example

3 1 4 (00000011 00000001 00000100)
would become
0 48 4 4 (000000 110000 000100 000100)

If they were using a 6-bit char size. The only way to preserve the values 
would be to send a visual representation via a display monitor of our own 
design; and even for that simply 3 digits won't cut it. Firstly, we 
wouldn't even know if they read left to right. They could read right to 
left or vertically like old japanese manuscripts. Plus, no alien is going 
to look at "314314314314314314" and say, "THESE PEOPLE ARE GENIUSES"

The part about not finding patterns is a "no shit sherlock", because I just 
stated that earlier to explain why an audio recording of pi wouldn't work 
either (despite other things such as not knowing if they use compressed 
streams or plain pulse code modulation, nor the sample rate of their 
devices)

In fact, lets just rule out all communication whatsoever, because I highly 
doubt a species advanced enough to traverse galaxies floats around in their 
spaceships communicating through unsecure channels. Even if we did send 
them something, their software would most likely ignore it anyway.

And finally, you miss the entire point altogether, if pi does not exist in 
their mathematical equations, then it does absolutely nothing to show our 
intelligence.

[quote]
"If they don't get it it doesn't matter because they still will be able to 
pick up the pattern of our message"

WHAT PATTERN? The pattern of pi? There is no pattern you idiot  (facepalm)

comments.text:
+Chuckles Squad About the robot part ... Well, we have already invented a 
system to deter that eventuality even coming anywhere near possible. The 
Three Laws of Robotics, created by Isaac Asimov. And although there are 
more than three, which were added by other authors of Science Fiction, 
making them more than three, they're still considered the Three Laws, 
which, the foundation of includes: 1. A robot cannot harm a human, or, 
through inaction, allow a human to come to harm.  2. A robot must obey the 
orders given to it by human beings, except where such orders would conflict 
with the First Law.  3. A robot must protect its own existence as long as 
such protection does not conflict with the First or Second Laws.

These laws, which would be programmed into any form of Artificial 
Intelligence that we will/might/would/could make, would be almost necessary 
if one were to have an AI, as without these laws in motion, the AI 
would/could become an Actual Intelligence, and would try to act out the 
situation you previously stated. Also, it would make sense to have such 
rules implemented so as to avoid anything like this, so I highly doubt a 
race of beings so sophisticated that they can travel hundreds, thousand, 
millions, billions, etc. light-years in distance to reach us would miss 
this simple notation.

These Laws were invented long before any advancements to any sort of robot 
more high-tech than a vacuum-cleaner were done.

comments.text:
+Patrick Golden
Please tell me, what is it that Earth has that a such advanced alien race 
cannot refine, or form on their own on a different planet?

Ok, I'll throw you a bone. The single most unique feature earth has over 
99% of other planets is our atmosphere with... 26% oxygen, if I remember 
correctly which does react with other elements over time, which makes those 
elements rare in uninhabited planets. But which elements are included in 
this category? Rust... that's about it. Not a very compelling argument.

Also, you claim that there is 0 risk in assaulting earth? News flash, 
combat is NEVER risk free, even if your opponent was unarmed and you have a 
gun, the risk factor is NEVER 0. This has been demonstrated numerous times 
in army practice lessons and war games countless times. One rookie loads a 
mortar incorrectly, 3 people dead, easy. Fighter jets collide with each 
other in air, injury free survival is fairly rare.

It really doesn't matter how many safeguards the aliens have on their 
weapons / crafts, mistakes and equipment failure is ALWAYS an option and 
when that happens, it is often lethal when weapons, or super high speed 
crafts are involved.

Thus it is ALWAYS safer to secure uninhabited planets, ESPECIALLY since 
there are billions and billions of uninhabited planets EVERYWHERE!

This is why even the notion of space warfare is idiotic to me, unless 
you're talking about a Star Wars, or Mass Effect type of situation where 
you have dozens of different civilizations interacting. However that is a 
far bigger assumption than assuming only 1 such technological race.

comments.text:
+Caldera You're thinking in a very micro mindset, that a whole planet - 
ours in particular - offers absolutely nothing of value, which is why the 
aliens would be so intellectually-superior in the first place.

If we send a response, we make them aware that we have developed the planet 
into something useful that may contain things an uninhabited planet does 
not have. Regardless of that, our planet likely offers much more than the 
myriad rocks sitting in space. Given the elements we have discovered that 
another planet may not have, plus given that these elements are combined in 
countless ways throughout nature and other places, you don't know how these 
could prove useful to a planet that has entirely different elements and 
resources than us.

You don't know if resistance is a concern to them. Given that they would be 
traveling, presumably, light years across space, as you mentioned, making 
them far superior to us, then why do you have the audacity to assume we 
would even begin to have the means to resist invasion? We could be wiped 
out in a second; you don't know.

Beyond that, you also assume that the only lifeforms involved would be the 
one foreign planet's and us. How do you know the aliens don't also have 
tensions between even other alien civilizations that we don't know about? 
There could be intergalactic warfare going on right now and we have no 
idea. Based on that, with our industrialization and anything else we may 
offer in nature, our planet may prove to be a useful staging ground for any 
kind of alien struggles going on right now.

And even if the invasion were for labor, I'm sure you know that slaves were 
once transported from Africa to America and were viewed as worthless and 
not even human or intelligent in any way. So why think we wouldn't be 
viewed the same? Earth can be their Africa; it doesn't matter the distance 
traveled to transport us slaves to another planet, just as slaves sailed 
across the ocean to America. It's the same concept and quite a likely one.

All that said, plus the many more scenarios that none of us likely have the 
intelligence to foresee, I don't think you're really in any position to say 
that our planet or humans would be in no way useful to an invading species 
that you have absolutely no information on.
comments.author: Patrick Golden

comments.text:
+failstickmen Yeah but there are lots of variables, most all it's mutation 
rate. A complex pathogen will quite likely not be able to mutate fast 
enough to infect us. And if it ever did, it would take so long we'd see it 
coming a mile away and prepare for it adequately.

If it was a very simple pathogen (like an RNA virus), and it's normal 
target (the aliens) had close enough DNA to us, then there's a decent 
chance it could mutate fast enough to infect us before we could stop it. On 
Earth we have a few viruses that a very good at infecting between species 
(eg. Influenza variants swine/bird/human), and they are very problematic, 
because, not only does their high mutation rate mean they can cross 
species, but it means that it's very difficult to vaccinate against; every 
time a virus mutates, you'll need a new vaccine for the new strain, because 
the previous vaccine will only be effective against the old strain. If it 
mutates fast enough that it stops us from reliably developing a vaccine, 
then that makes it very, very dangerous to us as a species.

comments.text:
+phdinaw3som3 

I go by the following assumptions.

1. The dominant species on a planet will be carnivores; this source of 
energy is the only one sufficient to power the brain required to form a 
space fairing civilization. Thus, evolution will select for the 
most aggressive.

2. The dominant species will also be tribal; a species that stays by 
itself,even if it is highly intelligent, can't build a village let alone
a vessel that can travel the stars.

3. Tribal societies will inevitably come to blows over issues such
as access to resources, especially during times of scarcity. They won't 
be driven by human nature, but they will be driven to survive.

4. Over time, some tribes will come to be dominant over the others due to 
some combination of advantages. They will be able to assemble bigger groups 
with which they can gather more resources and power. As history progresses 
the most successful groups will likely learn that it is best to use 
political means and soft power to achieve their interests rather than brute 
force.

5. As they advance to the status of a space fairing civilization their 
resource requirements will grow exponentially and they will
seek to guarantee their access to the resources they need.

6. Eventually, assuming space fairing life is common, they will encounter 
other civilizations with the same motivations and needs as them; not all of 
these 
conflicts will be resolved peacefully and some might go on to be decades or 
centuries
long confrontations. 

That's what i base it on; space faring civilizations will be driven by the 
same
survival instincts we are, which is what drives conflict when you really 
drill down
into it.

I only have human history as a model and it might not be accurate. But 
here's the thing;people who say aliens won't act anything like humans are 
basing that assumption on 
next to nothing.

Until we actually meet them, my guess is as good as yours.
comments.author: Burkutace27

comments.text:
The idea is that for anything to arrive here from another planet, it would 
have to use a ship with capabilities far beyond anything we've managed to 
build. To reach the nearest star to our system (Proxima Centauri) using the 
fastest spacecraft we have (New Horizons, which is an unmanned craft) it 
would take 78,000 years. And that's just to get to our next door neighbors, 
which we know cannot support life. To reach the nearest planet that can 
MAYBE support life, it would take more than 240,000 years. That's a long 
time for someone to derp along in a little spaceship with no goal in mind, 
simply to get lucky and stumble across our planet. If someone manages to 
get here, it's a safe bet that they're using technology way more advanced 
than our crappy little shuttles only designed to pop over to the the ISS.
